plain_title: Can cognitive rehabilitation (therapy to help with memory and daily tasks) help people with dementia manage everyday activities?
key_messages: For people with mild to moderate dementia, cognitive rehabilitation (therapy to help with memory and daily tasks) helps them to better manage the specific everyday activities they choose to work on. The review did not report on any unwanted or harmful effects.
The therapy may also have small benefits for the quality of life of care partners (family members or friends who provide support).

However, the findings of this review are based largely on one big study. More research is needed to confirm these results and to understand the best ways to use this therapy to help people with dementia.

background.subheading: What is cognitive rehabilitation for dementia?
background.content: Dementia causes problems with thinking skills, such as memory, which can make it harder for people to manage everyday activities and live independently. Cognitive rehabilitation is a personalised therapy that aims to help people with mild to moderate dementia overcome these challenges. In cognitive rehabilitation, the person with dementia works with a therapist to identify specific, practical goals for activities they find difficult. Together, they find new strategies and ways to manage these tasks, with the aim of improving their ability to handle daily life.

background.subheading: What did we want to find out?
background.content: We wanted to find out if cognitive rehabilitation helps people with mild to moderate dementia to better manage the everyday activities they have chosen to work on. We also wanted to understand its effects on other outcomes, such as quality of life, for both the person with dementia and their family members or carers.

methods.content: We searched for studies called randomized controlled trials (where people are randomly assigned to different treatment groups) that compared cognitive rehabilitation with usual care for people with mild-to-moderate dementia. We then combined the results from these studies and rated our confidence in the evidence.

results.content: The review included six randomised controlled trials with a total of 1702 people with mild-to-moderate dementia. The mean age of participants across the studies ranged from 76 to 80 years, and the proportion of men ranged from 29.4% to 79.3%. Most participants for whom a specific diagnosis was reported had Alzheimer's disease. The studies compared cognitive rehabilitation with usual care. Follow-up was conducted between 3 and 12 months after the end of treatment.

results.subheading: Main results: Cognitive rehabilitation helps people with mild-to-moderate dementia manage their everyday activities
results.content:
For people with mild to moderate dementia, cognitive rehabilitation causes a large increase in their ability to manage the everyday activities they chose to work on. This improvement is seen at the end of the treatment period and continues for several months afterwards. The treatment also slightly increases a person's confidence in their own abilities and their immediate memory. It probably also slightly improves their ability to focus on sounds for several months.

For care partners, the treatment slightly improves the social aspects of their quality of life and probably improves the psychological aspects of their quality of life for several months.

Cognitive rehabilitation probably makes little to no difference to the person's overall quality of life, anxiety, or general functional ability immediately after treatment. It may make little to no difference to other aspects of their memory and attention.

limitations: Our confidence in the evidence is only moderate because of concerns about two main issues. It is possible that people in the studies were aware of which treatment they were getting, and there are not enough studies to be certain about all of the results.
currency: The evidence is up to date to October 2022 of search.
